prompt: Give a quote about Paul, Johnson, Hamilton.
response:
In 1997, historian 
Paul Johnson
 wrote that Hamilton was a "genius—the only one of the Founding Fathers fully entitled to that accolade—and he had the elusive, indefinable characteristics of genius."






Early life and education


Hamilton was born on January 11, 1755, or 1757,
 in 
Charlestown
, the capital of 
Nevis
 in the 
British Leeward Islands
, where he spent his childhood. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about James, Hamilton, Rachel.
response:
James Hamilton later abandoned Rachel Lavien and their two sons, ostensibly to "spar[e] [her] a charge of 
bigamy
...after finding out that her first husband intend[ed] to divorce her under Danish law on grounds of adultery and desertion."
 Lavien then moved with their two children back to Saint Croix, where she supported them by managing a small store in 
Christiansted
. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Lavien's, In, probate.
response:
In 
probate court
, Lavien's "first husband seized her estate"
 and obtained the few valuables that she had owned, including some household silver. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Biographer, Ron, Chernow.
response:
Biographer 
Ron Chernow
 found the letter astounding because "for all its bombastic excesses, it does seem wondrous [that a] self-educated clerk could write with such verve and gusto" and that a teenage boy produced an apocalyptic "fire-and-brimstone sermon" viewing the hurricane as a "divine rebuke to human vanity and pomposity."
 The essay impressed community leaders, who collected a fund to send Hamilton to the North American colonies for his education. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Washington, Aides, Hamilton.
response:
Washington believed that "Aides de camp are persons in whom entire confidence must be placed and it requires men of abilities to execute the duties with propriety and dispatch."


Hamilton served four years as Washington's chief staff aide. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about This, July, Hamilton.
response:
This continued until early July 1781, when Hamilton submitted a letter to Washington with his 
commission
 enclosed, "thus tacitly threatening to resign if he didn't get his desired command."


On July 31, Washington relented and assigned Hamilton as commander of 
a battalion of light infantry companies
 of the 1st and 2nd New York Regiments and two provisional companies from Connecticut. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about He, James, Duane.

the confederation itself is defective and requires to be altered; it is neither fit for war, nor peace."


While on Washington's staff, Hamilton had become frustrated with the decentralized nature of the wartime Continental Congress, particularly its dependence upon the states for voluntary financial support that was not often forthcoming. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, Washington, to.
response: Hamilton wrote Washington to suggest that Hamilton covertly "take direction" of the officers' efforts to secure redress, to secure continental funding but keep the army within the limits of moderation. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about After, Constitution, United.
response: After the Constitution of the United States went into effect, Hamilton said, "One of the first subjects of deliberation with the new Congress will be the independence of Kentucky, for which the southern states will be anxious. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Vermont, Union, to.

prompt: Give a quote about He, Hamilton, James.
response:
He proposed
 to have an elected president and elected 
senators
 who would serve for life, contingent upon "good behavior" and subject to removal for corruption or abuse; this idea contributed later to the hostile view of Hamilton as a monarchist sympathizer, held by James Madison. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about According, Madison's, Hamilton.
response: According to Madison's notes, Hamilton said in regards to the executive, "The English model was the only good one on this subject. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Let, Hamilton, executive.

Let one executive be appointed for life who dares execute his powers."


Hamilton argued, "And let me observe that an executive is less dangerous to the liberties of the people when in office during life than for seven years. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about But, Madison, Hamilton's.

impeachment
, the term 'monarchy' cannot apply ..."

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton's, No, that.
response: Hamilton's highlights included discussion that although republics have been culpable for disorders in the past, advances in the "science of politics" had fostered principles that ensured that those abuses could be prevented, such as the division of powers, legislative checks and balances, an independent judiciary, and legislators that were represented by electors (No. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Thomas, Jefferson, Hamilton.
response: Thomas Jefferson wrote years afterward that Hamilton had a discussion with him, around this time period, about the capital of the United States being relocated to Virginia by means of a "pill" that "would be peculiarly bitter to the Southern States, and that some concomitant measure should be adopted to sweeten it a little to them". — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Jefferson, Necessary, Proper.
response:
Jefferson dismissed the 
Necessary and Proper Clause
 as reasoning for the creation of a national bank, stating that the enumerated powers "can all be carried into execution without a bank."
 Along with Randolph and Jefferson's objections, Washington's involvement in the movement of the capital from Philadelphia is also thought to be a reason for his hesitation. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, Necessary, Washington.
response:
In response to the objection of the clause, Hamilton stated that "Necessary often means no more than needful, requisite, incidental, useful, or conductive to", and the bank was a "convenient species of medium in which [taxes] are to be paid."
 Washington would eventually sign the bill into law. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, President, Washington.
response:
In response to the rebellion, believing compliance with the laws was vital to the establishment of federal authority, Hamilton accompanied to the rebellion's site President Washington, General 
Henry "Light Horse Harry" Lee
, and more federal troops than Washington had usually commanded during the Revolution. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Among, Hamilton, United.
response:

infant industries
" so they can achieve 
economies of scale
, by levying protective duties on imported foreign goods that were also manufactured in the United States,
 for withdrawing duties levied on raw materials needed for domestic manufacturing,
 and pecuniary boundaries. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Historian, George, Herring.
response: Historian George Herring notes the "remarkable and fortuitous economic and diplomatic gains" produced by the Treaty. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, Some, her.
response: Hamilton recorded her address and subsequently delivered $30 personally to her boarding house, where she led him into her bedroom and "Some conversation ensued from which it was quickly apparent that other than pecuniary consolation would be acceptable". — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about After, Hamilton, Reynolds.

prompt: Give a quote about Jay, Supreme, Court.
response: Jay, who had resigned from the Supreme Court to become Governor of New York, wrote on the back of a letter, "Proposing a measure for party purposes which it would not become me to adopt," and declined to reply. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, Jefferson, Burr.

prompt: Give a quote about Hamilton, Jews, He.

 He believed that Jewish achievement was a result of 
divine providence
:



The state and progress of the Jews, from their earliest history to the present time, has been so entirely out of the ordinary course of human affairs, is it not then a fair conclusion, that the cause also is an

 one—in other words, that it is the effect of some great providential plan? — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

response:
Ron Chernow
, in his 2004 
biography of Hamilton
, argued that, while there is "no definite proof" that Hamilton personally owned slaves, "oblique hints" in Hamilton's papers suggest "he and Eliza may have owned one or two household slaves."

Allan McLane Hamilton
, interpreted some of these journal entries as being purchases for himself. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)

colonization
 of free people of color outside the United States, which many contemporaries considered essential to any plan for emancipation. — (Alexander Hamilton, Wikipedia)
